head.title: Books Worth a Spot On a Car Buff's Shelf

hedline.hl1: Books Worth a Spot On a Car Buff's Shelf

block.p: The Classic Era By Beverly Rae Kimes Illustrated. 720 pages. Classic Car Club of America, 2001.

The author presents a detailed year-by-year rundown of the American and European auto industry from 1925 through 1948, but don't expect any mention of plebeian Chevrolets, Fords or Dodges. As the title implies, this is a chronicle of the kings (and princes) of the road -- the higher-priced brands like Stutz, Cord, Auburn and Rolls-Royce (particularly the cars from the American factory in Springfield, Mass.).
The Classic Era By Beverly Rae Kimes Illustrated. 720 pages. Classic Car Club of America, 2001.

The author presents a detailed year-by-year rundown of the American and European auto industry from 1925 through 1948, but don't expect any mention of plebeian Chevrolets, Fords or Dodges. As the title implies, this is a chronicle of the kings (and princes) of the road -- the higher-priced brands like Stutz, Cord, Auburn and Rolls-Royce (particularly the cars from the American factory in Springfield, Mass.).

Each chapter is a thorough almanac of the year's activities, including executive shuffling; a necrology of the marques that went under; and the latest engineering breakthroughs. Ms. Kimes is a facile writer, so the wheels never become mired. Besides, there are plenty of photos to linger over.

Not that there is any reason to hurry to the end of this book: we all know who's left standing, for example, in the Packard-Cadillac showdown. And the palette of body colors forced a buyer to choose among whimsically named shades like Fenimore and Laurel (two greens) or Yedaz (tan). Even then, luxury had its price.
